comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
New York Times, September 26, 1913:

"Amateurs were in the lead yesterday at the opening session of the sixteenth annual horse show of the Morristown Field Club, which was held on the organization's enclosure at Morristown, N. J.  With stands filled and the parking spaces preempted with scores of automobiles the affair quite kept up its former standing as a medium to attract hundreds of people well known in society.

............................................................................................

"One of the classes which took with spectators was the pony jumping, the entries being ridden by children over brush jumps. Josephine Jenks of Mt. Kemble, Morristown, carried off the palm with her mother's black mare, Frills, a 12.3 pony, which went at the barriers like a steeplechaser and carried her youthful rider to a somewhat easy victory."
